results.title: Bill Onus hosting Alcheringa
results.brief_description: To Bill Onus, sharing his culture was an act of resistance and reclamation of power. Through Forgotten People(1967) and Alcheringa (1962), Bill demonstrated his ongoing commitment to self-representation through screen culture.

constellations_other.name: Connecting through film
constellations_other.description: Film acts like a time capsule to our collective past. Capturing our most treasured moments with family has never been more accessible, with technology right at our fingers.

results.title: Bill Onus campaigns ‘Vote Yes for Aboriginal Rights’
results.credit_line: Courtesy AAP Image / National Library of Australia
results.brief_description: Yorta Yorta activist, artist and entrepreneur Bill Onus shared his culture as an act of resistance and reclamation of power. He helped establish the Aborigines Advancement League and campaigned for the ‘YES’ vote in the 1967 Referendum.
results.title_for_label: Bill Onus campaigns ‘Vote Yes for Aboriginal Rights’
results.description: Bill Onus, President of the Victorian Aborigines’ Advancement League (right), participating as the only Aboriginal in the march for Aboriginal Rights referendum on May 29, 1967.
description_for_label: Bill Onus, President of the Victorian Aborigines’ Advancement League (right), participating as the only Aboriginal in the march for Aboriginal Rights referendum on May 29, 1967.
results.credit_line_for_label: Courtesy AAP Image / National Library of Australia

results.title: ‘How to throw a boomerang’ leaflet
results.brief_description: Yorta Yorta activist, artist and entrepreneur Bill Onus shared his culture as an act of resistance and reclamation of power. Through his factory and shop, Aboriginal Enterprises, he shared his art and culture, selling boomerangs and other pieces.

results.title: The Family Law Production stills
results.brief_description: Based on Benjamin Law’s 2010 book, The Family Law was the first Australian TV show to focus on an Asian Australian family. While it explores familiar stories about an everyday family, it offers a unique perspective on what it means to be Australian today.

results.title: The Family Law exhibition footage
results.brief_description: The Australian landscape is never just a setting. It’s meditative, motivational and menacing; a character that empowers, intimidates and inspires. This artwork examines how representations of Australian landscapes have evolved from being dominated by the Outback to the suburbs and cities.
results.description:
Fourteen-year-old Benjamin Law is desperate to win his school’s talent show. Not only must he chart a course to high-school stardom, but he also needs to navigate all the issues of Australian adolescence: embarrassing parents, bickering siblings, school bullies, best friends and his own sexuality.

Based on Benjamin Law’s 2010 book of the same name, The Family Law was the first Australian TV show to focus on an Asian Australian family. While it explores familiar stories about an everyday family, it offers a uniquely Asian Australian perspective on what it means to be Australian today.
description_for_label:
Fourteen-year-old Benjamin Law is desperate to win his school’s talent show. Not only must he chart a course to high-school stardom, but he also needs to navigate all the issues of Australian adolescence: embarrassing parents, bickering siblings, school bullies, best friends and his own sexuality.

Based on Benjamin Law’s 2010 book of the same name, The Family Law was the first Australian TV show to focus on an Asian Australian family. While it explores familiar stories about an everyday family, it offers a uniquely Asian Australian perspective on what it means to be Australian today.
